<ce:section-title id="sectitle0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">Six new triorganotin complexes, [(R<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CC<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>NS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (R = Me: <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; <ce:italic>n-</ce:italic>Bu: <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [(R<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CC<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>S)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (R = Me: <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>; <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-Bu: <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), [(R<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>S)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (R = Me: <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>; <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-Bu: <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) have been obtained by the reaction of R<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnCl (R = Me, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-Bu) with the corresponding dicarboxylate ligands (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> = 6,6’-dithiodinicotinic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> = 2,2’-dithiodibenzoic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> = dithiodiglycolic acid). All the compounds were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, NMR, and X-ray crystallography. The structural analysis reveals that complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> display various 2D metal-organic framework structures including wave-like, corrugated and double-layer, which is attributed to the twisting of the ligands around flexible S<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>S bonds. Additionally, <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> cytotoxic investigation of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> were also conducted by employing human cervix cell lines (HeLa) and human lung cancer cells (A549).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Six new triorganotin complexes, [(R3Sn)2(O2CC5H3NS)2]n (R=Me: 1; n-Bu: 2), [(R3Sn)2(O2CC6H4S)2]n (R=Me: 3; n-Bu: 4), [(R3Sn)2(O2CCH2S)2]n (R=Me: 5; n-Bu: 6) have been obtained by the reaction of R3SnCl (R=Me, n-Bu) with the corresponding dicarboxylate ligands (H2L1=6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid, H2L2=2,2'-dithiodibenzoic acid, H2L3=dithiodiglycolic acid). All the compounds were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, NMR, and X-ray crystallography. The structural analysis reveals that complexes 1-6 display various 2D metal-organic framework structures including wave-like, corrugated and double-layer, which is attributed to the twisting of the ligands around flexible SS bonds. Additionally, in vitro cytotoxic investigation of complexes 1-6 were also conducted by employing human cervix cell lines (HeLa) and human lung cancer cells (A549).

Metal-directed self-assembly built from inorganic metal ions and organic polycarboxylate linkers has become a powerful tool for constructions of CPs []. Meanwhile, relevant systems with organometallic species have attracted considerable attention and been widely studied []. As a subclass of organometallics, organotin compounds possess versatile structures [] including ladder, drum, butterflies, cluster and cage, as well as extensive applications [] such as reagents or catalysts in organic synthesis, pesticides in agriculture, bactericidal agents. Particularly in recent years, organotin compounds gained much attention for their significant antifungal, antibacterial, antitumor properties []. A series of studies on anti-tumor activity of organotin compounds and their possible implementation on cancer, have already been reported recently. Much to our surprise, organotin(IV) compounds have shown potential in the prevention and treatment of cancer by inducing differentiation suppression and apoptosis, which are considered as biologically active metallopharmaceuticals []. These superior performances have motivated researchers to synthesize and study organotin compounds with diverse structures and benign biological properties. Thus, organotin has been a hot research area of organometallics.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Six new triorganotin complexes based on three dicarboxylate ligands containing flexible S-S bonds.

Various 2D metal-organic framework structures including wave-like, corrugated and double-layer.

Cytotoxic investigation demonstrate that complexes with R = n-Bu exhibit superior activity than that with R= Me.

Introduction

Reasonable design and syntheses of coordination polymers (CPs) have been continuously gaining the focus attention and achieved rapid progress in recent years, which have important applications including gas storage/separation, catalysis, magnetism, electronics, and chemical sensing []. Metal-directed self-assembly built from inorganic metal ions and organic polycarboxylate linkers has become a powerful tool for constructions of CPs []. Meanwhile, relevant systems with organometallic species have attracted considerable attention and been widely studied []. As a subclass of organometallics, organotin compounds possess versatile structures [] including ladder, drum, butterflies, cluster and cage, as well as extensive applications [] such as reagents or catalysts in organic synthesis, pesticides in agriculture, bactericidal agents. Particularly in recent years, organotin compounds gained much attention for their significant antifungal, antibacterial, antitumor properties []. A series of studies on anti-tumor activity of organotin compounds and their possible implementation on cancer, have already been reported recently. Much to our surprise, organotin(IV) compounds have shown potential in the prevention and treatment of cancer by inducing differentiation suppression and apoptosis, which are considered as biologically active metallopharmaceuticals []. These superior performances have motivated researchers to synthesize and study organotin compounds with diverse structures and benign biological properties. Thus, organotin has been a hot research area of organometallics.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">As we all know, rigid multitopic ligands are often employed to construct CPs with specific topologies due to the predictability of the resulting networks, whereas flexible ligands could adopt different conformations and coordination modes according to the geometric requirements of metal ions. So the ligands are crucially important to construct frameworks of CPs, and we usually tend to select flexible ligands to construct organotin coordination polymers, especially organic carboxylate ligands. The selection of organic carboxylate ligands should be based on following considerations: (a) the carboxyl groups can be deprotonated to generate monodentate and bidentate coordination modes; (b) they hold flexibility so as to bend to require its conformation to coordinate to metal centers; (c) long length between two carboxyl groups is favorable to build interesting macrocycle structures. Inspired by the above aspects, employing 6,6’-dithiodinicotinic acid, 2,2’-dithiodibenzoic acid and dithiodiglycolic acid as ligands is of significant. So the reactions of R<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnCl (R = Me, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-Bu) with these three ligands were conducted and six novel triorganotin coordination polymers were obtained, which exhibit various 2D metal-organic framework structures constructed from macrocycles.</ce:para>

The selection of organic carboxylate ligands should be based on following considerations: (a) the carboxyl groups can be deprotonated to generate monodentate and bidentate coordination modes; (b) they hold flexibility so as to bend to require its conformation to coordinate to metal centers; (c) long length between two carboxyl groups is favorable to build interesting macrocycle structures. Inspired by the above aspects, employing 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid, 2,2'-dithiodibenzoic acid and dithiodiglycolic acid as ligands is of significant. So the reactions of R3SnCl (R=Me, n-Bu) with these three ligands were conducted and six novel triorganotin coordination polymers were obtained, which exhibit various 2D metal-organic framework structures constructed from macrocycles.

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0035">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0040">Syntheses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The synthetic procedures for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">As is shown in , the reactions of R<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnCl (R = Me, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-Bu) with the corresponding dicarboxylate ligands (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> = 6,6’-dithiodinicotinic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> = 2,2’-dithiodibenzoic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> = dithiodiglycolic acid) in a 2:1 molar ratio afforded [(R<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CC<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>NS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (R = Me: <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; <ce:italic>n-</ce:italic>Bu: <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [(R<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CC<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>S)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (R = Me: <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>; <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-Bu: <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) and [(R<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>S)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (R = Me: <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>; <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-Bu: <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>). Thus, the products were easily isolated and characterized. Attempts to crystallize these complexes with diethyl ether formed transparent colorless crystals of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Syntheses

The synthetic procedures for complexes 1-6 are given in  .

As is shown in , the reactions of R3SnCl (R=Me, n-Bu) with the corresponding dicarboxylate ligands (H2L1=6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid, H2L2=2,2'-dithiodibenzoic acid, H2L3=dithiodiglycolic acid) in a 2:1 molar ratio afforded [(R3Sn)2(O2CC5H3NS)2]n (R=Me: 1; n-Bu: 2), [(R3Sn)2(O2CC6H4S)2]n (R=Me: 3; n-Bu: 4) and [(R3Sn)2(O2CCH2S)2]n (R=Me: 5; n-Bu: 6). Thus, the products were easily isolated and characterized. Attempts to crystallize these complexes with diethyl ether formed transparent colorless crystals of complexes 1-6.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0045">IR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The IR spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> were recorded in the range of 4000–400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and give valuable supporting information in structural elucidation. The typical absorptions in the region 453-480 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> and 512-580 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup>, which are absent in the spectrum of the potassium salts of ligands, are assigned to the Sn-O and Sn-C stretching vibration modes. Also, the strong absorption bands that appear at 1546–1577 and 1383–1399 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in these spectra are assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> moiety, respectively. All these values are well consistent with those detected in a number of organotin(IV)–oxygen derivatives []. In addition, as reported in the literature, the difference of Δ<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic> between the wavenumber for ν<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf>(COO) and ν<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf>(COO) allows one to distinguish the coordination modes of the ligand. When the Sn atoms are in coordination with the O atoms of the carboxylate group, the asymmetric vibration ν<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf> (COO) decreases and the symmetric vibration ν<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf> (COO) increases, so Δν decreases []. In the IR spectra of the potassium salts (K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L), the ν<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf> (COO) appear at 1584-1588 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> and ν<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf> (COO) at 1384-1391 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup>. The Δν values for three potassium salts are 197 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup>, 198 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> and 204 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup>. The Δν values for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> (162 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 186 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 193 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 163 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, 178 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, 167 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) are less than that of corresponding potassium salts, which reveals that three ligands adopted bidentate coordination mode, without exception.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
IR spectra

The IR spectra of complexes 1-6 were recorded in the range of 4000-400cm-1, and give valuable supporting information in structural elucidation. The typical absorptions in the region 453-480 cm-1 and 512-580 cm-1, which are absent in the spectrum of the potassium salts of ligands, are assigned to the Sn-O and Sn-C stretching vibration modes. Also, the strong absorption bands that appear at 1546-1577 and 1383-1399cm-1 in these spectra are assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the COO- moiety, respectively. All these values are well consistent with those detected in a number of organotin(IV)-oxygen derivatives []. In addition, as reported in the literature, the difference of Δν between the wavenumber for νas(COO) and νs(COO) allows one to distinguish the coordination modes of the ligand. When the Sn atoms are in coordination with the O atoms of the carboxylate group, the asymmetric vibration νas (COO) decreases and the symmetric vibration νs (COO) increases, so Δν decreases []. In the IR spectra of the potassium salts (K2L), the νas (COO) appear at 1584-1588 cm-1 and νs (COO) at 1384-1391 cm-1. The Δν values for three potassium salts are 197 cm-1, 198 cm-1 and 204 cm-1. The Δν values for complexes 1-6 (162 cm-1 for 1, 186 cm-1 for 2, 193 cm-1 for 3, 163 cm-1 for 4, 178 cm-1 for 5, 167 cm-1 for 6) are less than that of corresponding potassium salts, which reveals that three ligands adopted bidentate coordination mode, without exception.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0050">NMR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra show the signals of the <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H proton are absent in these compounds, indicating the formation of Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond. In the <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectrum of complexes, the chemical shifts of protons on ligands exhibit signals at 7.57-9.06 ppm as singlets and doublets for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 7.19-8.05 ppm as multiplets for complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>-<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, and 3.61-3.65 ppm as singlets for complexes <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>-<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. Methyl protons (Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> moiety) of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> show triplet peaks at 0.51, 0.56 and 0.62 ppm respectively, along with the coupling constant <ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>(<ce:sup loc="post">119</ce:sup>Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H) [ 36 Hz for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 32 Hz for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 34 Hz for <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> ], which falls in the range of four-coordinated trigonal bipyramidal geometry around the tin atoms in solution state [,]. The <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph> skeleton of complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> appear in the range of 1.27-1.70 ppm as multiplets. And the terminal methyl groups of <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-butyl give characteristic signals at 0.91, 0.92 and 0.91 ppm as triplets respectively, with the coupling constant <ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>(<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H-<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H) = 8 Hz for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. The information accords well with what the IR data has revealed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
NMR spectra

The 1H NMR spectra show the signals of the CO2H proton are absent in these compounds, indicating the formation of SnO bond. In the 1H NMR spectrum of complexes, the chemical shifts of protons on ligands exhibit signals at 7.57-9.06 ppm as singlets and doublets for complexes 1-2, 7.19-8.05 ppm as multiplets for complexes 3-4, and 3.61-3.65 ppm as singlets for complexes 5-6. Methyl protons (SnCH3 moiety) of complexes 1, 3 and 5 show triplet peaks at 0.51, 0.56 and 0.62 ppm respectively, along with the coupling constant 2 J(119Sn 1H) [ 36 Hz for 1, 32 Hz for 3 and 34 Hz for 5 ], which falls in the range of four-coordinated trigonal bipyramidal geometry around the tin atoms in solution state [,]. The CH2 CH2 CH2  skeleton of complexes 2, 4 and 6 appear in the range of 1.27-1.70 ppm as multiplets. And the terminal methyl groups of n-butyl give characteristic signals at 0.91, 0.92 and 0.91 ppm as triplets respectively, with the coupling constant 2 J(1H-1H) = 8 Hz for 2, 4 and 6. The information accords well with what the IR data has revealed.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectra of all compounds show a significant downfield shift of all carbon resonances compared with the free ligands because of an electron-density transfer from the ligands to the metal atoms. The characteristic signals at <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> = 167.53–174.25 ppm are attributed to the COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> groups in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. For complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the values of <ce:sup loc="post">119</ce:sup>Sn-<ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C coupling were calculated: <ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>(<ce:sup loc="post">119</ce:sup>Sn-<ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C) = 266 Hz for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 251 Hz for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, which lies in the range of four-coordinated tin atoms in solution state [,].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The 13C NMR spectra of all compounds show a significant downfield shift of all carbon resonances compared with the free ligands because of an electron-density transfer from the ligands to the metal atoms. The characteristic signals at δ=167.53-174.25ppm are attributed to the COO- groups in complexes 1-6. For complex 1 and 3, the values of 119Sn-13C coupling were calculated: 2 J(119Sn-13C) = 266 Hz for 1, 251 Hz for 3, which lies in the range of four-coordinated tin atoms in solution state [,].

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The <ce:sup loc="pre">119</ce:sup>Sn NMR spectrum of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> obtained only one signal at <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> = −22.98, 126.95, −3.56, 125.90, −21.68 and 125.02 ppm respectively, typical of a four-coordinated tin atom [,], which aren't accordance with the structures in crystalline state. On this basis, it can reasonably be assumed that the Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bonds of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> are probably dissociation in the solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The 119Sn NMR spectrum of complexes 1-6 obtained only one signal at δ=-22.98, 126.95, -3.56, 125.90, -21.68 and 125.02ppm respectively, typical of a four-coordinated tin atom [,], which aren't accordance with the structures in crystalline state. On this basis, it can reasonably be assumed that the SnO bonds of complexes 1-6 are probably dissociation in the solution.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0055">Crystal structure descriptions</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0060">Crystal structures of complexes 1-2</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the Monoclinic system with space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2(1)/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, and is a 2D wavelike framework polymer in the crystalline state. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>(a), the asymmetric unit contains two Me<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn units and one deprotonated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> ligand. In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the geometry around tin can be characterized by the geometric parameter τ, which can be calculated by using expression, τ = (β-α)/60. Here α is the axial angle, and β is the greater of the basal angles around Sn. τ value is equal to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for perfect trigonal bipyramidal, while zero for perfect square planar geometry. For complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the value of τ is 0.84 indicating Sn atoms are situated in a distorted penta-coordinated trigonal bipyramid geometry []. The equatorial plane is composed of three carbon atoms from Me<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn group, while the apical position is occupied by two oxygen atoms from two different H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> ligands. The O1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Sn1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O3 angle 175.7(4)º is close to linear arrangement. The sum of the angles subtended at the Sn1 atoms in the equatorial plane is 358.0°. The Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond lengths [Sn1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O1 2.488(12) Å and Sn1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O3 2.125(12) Å] are between the covalent bond length (2.13 Å) and the van der Waals radii (3.69 Å) [], indicating the compressed trigonal bipyramid environment of the metal ion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure descriptions

Crystal structures of complexes 1-2

Complex 1 crystallizes in the Monoclinic system with space group P2(1)/c, and is a 2D wavelike framework polymer in the crystalline state. As shown in  (a), the asymmetric unit contains two Me3Sn units and one deprotonated H2L1 ligand. In complex 1, the geometry around tin can be characterized by the geometric parameter τ, which can be calculated by using expression, τ = (β-α)/60. Here α is the axial angle, and β is the greater of the basal angles around Sn. τ value is equal to 1 for perfect trigonal bipyramidal, while zero for perfect square planar geometry. For complex 1, the value of τ is 0.84 indicating Sn atoms are situated in a distorted penta-coordinated trigonal bipyramid geometry []. The equatorial plane is composed of three carbon atoms from Me3Sn group, while the apical position is occupied by two oxygen atoms from two different H2L1 ligands. The O1Sn1O3 angle 175.7(4)º is close to linear arrangement. The sum of the angles subtended at the Sn1 atoms in the equatorial plane is 358.0°. The SnO bond lengths [Sn1O1 2.488(12) Å and Sn1O3 2.125(12) Å] are between the covalent bond length (2.13Å) and the van der Waals radii (3.69Å) [], indicating the compressed trigonal bipyramid environment of the metal ion.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Each H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> ligand is completely deprotonated, all the COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> groups adopted bidentate coordination mode, and four ligands are linked by four tin centers to form a 38-membered macrocycle, which is further linked to afford a two-dimensional sheet along the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane [(b)]. Interestingly, the two aromatic rings of the ligand are twisted around the S<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>S bond and possess a dihedral angle 66.869(329)° between them []. This results in a wavelike structural feature [
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Each H2L1 ligand is completely deprotonated, all the COO- groups adopted bidentate coordination mode, and four ligands are linked by four tin centers to form a 38-membered macrocycle, which is further linked to afford a two-dimensional sheet along the ab plane [(b)]. Interestingly, the two aromatic rings of the ligand are twisted around the SS bond and possess a dihedral angle 66.869(329)° between them []. This results in a wavelike structural feature [ ].

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The structure of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is similar to that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> except for the bond lengths and angles in the crystal structure, in which Sn atoms are situated in a distorted penta-coordinated trigonal bipyramid geometry. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is 2D wavelike polymeric structure generated as result of twisting of the ligand [
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structure of complex 2 is similar to that of 1 except for the bond lengths and angles in the crystal structure, in which Sn atoms are situated in a distorted penta-coordinated trigonal bipyramid geometry. Complex 2 is 2D wavelike polymeric structure generated as result of twisting of the ligand [ ].

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0065">Crystal structures of complex 3-4</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> crystallizes in the Monoclinic system with space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2, and displays a 2D double-layer framework structure. As illustrated in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>(a), the asymmetric unit is composed of two Me<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn units and one deprotonated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> ligand. Sn1 is also penta-coordinated by three carbon atoms (C15, C16, C17) from Me<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn groups and two oxygen atoms (O1, O3) from two bridge ligands. In case of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the value of τ is 0.83 indicating the Sn coordination geometry is also described as distorted trigonal bipyramid [], which is the same as that of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Two oxygen atoms from two bridge ligands occupy the axial position and axial angle O1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Sn1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O3 is 174.5(3)°, which is close to linear arrangement. The sum of the angles subtended at the tin atom in the equatorial plane is 359.4° for Sn1, so that the Sn1, C15, C16, and C17 atoms are almost in the same plane. All Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond distances are in the range of 2.199(7)-2.416(7) Å, which lie between the covalent bond length (2.13 Å) and the van der Waals radii (3.69 Å) []. As displayed in (b), two tin atoms together with two H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> ligands construct a 22-membered macrocycle. And it is further linked to nearest-neighbor macrocycles to give rise to a 2D double-layer framework [
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>]. The two aromatic rings of the ligand are twisted around the S<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>S bond with a dihedral angle 82.505(495)°, which play a significant role in assisting in constructing 2D double-layer network [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structures of complex 3-4

Complex 3 crystallizes in the Monoclinic system with space group C2, and displays a 2D double-layer framework structure. As illustrated in  (a), the asymmetric unit is composed of two Me3Sn units and one deprotonated H2L2 ligand. Sn1 is also penta-coordinated by three carbon atoms (C15, C16, C17) from Me3Sn groups and two oxygen atoms (O1, O3) from two bridge ligands. In case of complex 3, the value of τ is 0.83 indicating the Sn coordination geometry is also described as distorted trigonal bipyramid [], which is the same as that of complex 1. Two oxygen atoms from two bridge ligands occupy the axial position and axial angle O1Sn1O3 is 174.5(3)°, which is close to linear arrangement. The sum of the angles subtended at the tin atom in the equatorial plane is 359.4° for Sn1, so that the Sn1, C15, C16, and C17 atoms are almost in the same plane. All SnO bond distances are in the range of 2.199(7)-2.416(7) Å, which lie between the covalent bond length (2.13Å) and the van der Waals radii (3.69Å) []. As displayed in (b), two tin atoms together with two H2L2 ligands construct a 22-membered macrocycle. And it is further linked to nearest-neighbor macrocycles to give rise to a 2D double-layer framework [ ]. The two aromatic rings of the ligand are twisted around the SS bond with a dihedral angle 82.505(495)°, which play a significant role in assisting in constructing 2D double-layer network [].

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The structure of complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is roughly similar to that of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> except for the bond lengths and angles in the crystal structure [
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>]. But due to the twisted S<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>S bond of the ligand, complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> exhibits a 2D corrugated network which is different from complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structure of complex 4 is roughly similar to that of 3 except for the bond lengths and angles in the crystal structure [ ]. But due to the twisted SS bond of the ligand, complex 4 exhibits a 2D corrugated network which is different from complex 3 [].

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0070">X-ray crystallographic study of complexes <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> crystallizes in the Monoclinic system with space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2(1)/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>, and displays a 2D arched framework structure. Each of the tin atoms in complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> is essentially penta-coordinated, bound to three methyl groups and two carboxyl oxygen atoms. In complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, the value of τ is 0.774 showing the geometry of each tin atom can be described as a distorted trigonal bipyramid [], in which the apical positions are occupied by the oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups [
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor>(a)]. The axial angle O1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Sn1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O3 is 174.94(11)º, and the sum of the equatorial angles around the Sn1 atom is 359.5°. The bond distances of Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O [2.193(3)-2.425(3)] are in the normal range of organotin complexes [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic study of complexes 5-6 

Complex 5 crystallizes in the Monoclinic system with space group P2(1)/n, and displays a 2D arched framework structure. Each of the tin atoms in complex 5 is essentially penta-coordinated, bound to three methyl groups and two carboxyl oxygen atoms. In complex 5, the value of τ is 0.774 showing the geometry of each tin atom can be described as a distorted trigonal bipyramid [], in which the apical positions are occupied by the oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups [ (a)]. The axial angle O1Sn1O3 is 174.94(11)º, and the sum of the equatorial angles around the Sn1 atom is 359.5°. The bond distances of SnO [2.193(3)-2.425(3)] are in the normal range of organotin complexes [].

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0100" view="all">As depicted in (b), each H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> ligand is completely deprotonated, and four deprotonated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> ligands employs its two bidentate carboxylate groups to coordinate to four metal centers, which result into a 26-membered macrocycle. It is further linked to nearest-neighbor macrocycles to obtain 2D network. It is also interesting to see complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> exhibits 2D arched framework on account of the twisted S<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>S bond of the ligand with a dihedral angle 68.755(312)° [
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig8"></ce:float-anchor> and ].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As depicted in (b), each H2L3 ligand is completely deprotonated, and four deprotonated H2L3 ligands employs its two bidentate carboxylate groups to coordinate to four metal centers, which result into a 26-membered macrocycle. It is further linked to nearest-neighbor macrocycles to obtain 2D network. It is also interesting to see complex 5 exhibits 2D arched framework on account of the twisted SS bond of the ligand with a dihedral angle 68.755(312)° [  and ].

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0075">Anti-tumor activity of complexes 1–6 against HeLa and A549 cells</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">The <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> antitumor activity of all the synthesized compounds and cisplatin against human cervix cell lines (HeLa) and lung cancer cells (A549) were determined by MTT-based assays. A comparison of the half inhibition rates (IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> value) for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> and cisplatin is summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. The IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> (μmol/L) values, which are calculated from the dose survival curves, are obtained after 24 h of drug treatment in the MTT test.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Anti-tumor activity of complexes 1-6 against HeLa and A549cells

The in vitro antitumor activity of all the synthesized compounds and cisplatin against human cervix cell lines (HeLa) and lung cancer cells (A549) were determined by MTT-based assays. A comparison of the half inhibition rates (IC50 value) for complexes 1-6 and cisplatin is summarized in  . The IC50 (μmol/L) values, which are calculated from the dose survival curves, are obtained after 24h of drug treatment in the MTT test.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0115" view="all">As can be observed from , the IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> (μmol/L) values of complexes with R = trimethyl against HeLa and A549 cells are 31.34 ± 2.41 and 47.57 ± 2.62 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 27.71 ± 1.16 and 57.25 ± 3.03 (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), 40.20 ± 2.68 and 60.87 ± 3.58 (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), respectively. Whereas the IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> (μmol/L) values of complexes with R = <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-butyl against two cells are 0.42 ± 0.05 and 0.62 ± 0.08 (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), 0.41 ± 0.03 and 0.65 ± 0.09 (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), 0.55 ± 0.06 and 0.73 ± 0.10 (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>). The experimental results indicate complexes with R = <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-Bu (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) exhibit stronger activity than that with R = Me (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) against two cell lines, which is attributed to the presence of <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-butyl groups showing higher lipophilic character than the methyl groups so as to facilitate binding to biological molecules []. Additionally, the <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> antitumor activity of complexes with R = <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-Bu (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) is also higher than anti-cancer agent cisplatin.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As can be observed from , the IC50 (μmol/L) values of complexes with R=trimethyl against HeLa and A549cells are 31.34±2.41 and 47.57±2.62 (1), 27.71±1.16 and 57.25±3.03 (3), 40.20±2.68 and 60.87±3.58 (5), respectively. Whereas the IC50 (μmol/L) values of complexes with R=n-butyl against two cells are 0.42±0.05 and 0.62±0.08 (2), 0.41±0.03 and 0.65±0.09 (4), 0.55±0.06 and 0.73±0.10 (6). The experimental results indicate complexes with R=n-Bu (2, 4 and 6) exhibit stronger activity than that with R=Me (1, 3 and 5) against two cell lines, which is attributed to the presence of n-butyl groups showing higher lipophilic character than the methyl groups so as to facilitate binding to biological molecules []. Additionally, the in vitro antitumor activity of complexes with R=n-Bu (2, 4 and 6) is also higher than anti-cancer agent cisplatin.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0120" view="all">Also, the data analysis reveals that complexes with similar alkyl groups demonstrate different anticancer activities against the same cell line. We may speculate that the ligands and structures of compounds appear to play an important role in determining their antitumor activity, even with the same alkyl groups. As the experimental results are preliminary, further study on the antitumor mechanisms of these complexes is being studied in our lab.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Also, the data analysis reveals that complexes with similar alkyl groups demonstrate different anticancer activities against the same cell line. We may speculate that the ligands and structures of compounds appear to play an important role in determining their antitumor activity, even with the same alkyl groups. As the experimental results are preliminary, further study on the antitumor mechanisms of these complexes is being studied in our lab.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0080">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">In this paper, we have successfully synthesized and characterized six triorganotin polymers derived from 6,6’-dithiodinicotinic acid, 2,2’-dithiodibenzoic acid and dithiodiglycolic acid. In the crystalline state, the three flexible ligands adopted bidentate coordination mode and the central Sn atoms display a penta-coordination trigonal bipyramid geometry. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> exhibit diverse 2D metal-organic framework structures constructed from macrocycles, including wave-like, corrugated and double-layer, which is attributed to the twisting of the ligands around flexible S<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>S bonds. Remarkably, preliminarily <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> cytotoxic assessments of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> against HeLa and A549 cell lines demonstrate that complexes with R = <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-Bu (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) exhibit superior activity than that with R = Me (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>). This presented study enriches various structures of organotin dicarboxylates and promising possibility of designing benign biological metal-based drugs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this paper, we have successfully synthesized and characterized six triorganotin polymers derived from 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid, 2,2'-dithiodibenzoic acid and dithiodiglycolic acid. In the crystalline state, the three flexible ligands adopted bidentate coordination mode and the central Sn atoms display a penta-coordination trigonal bipyramid geometry. Complexes 1-6 exhibit diverse 2D metal-organic framework structures constructed from macrocycles, including wave-like, corrugated and double-layer, which is attributed to the twisting of the ligands around flexible SS bonds. Remarkably, preliminarily in vitro cytotoxic assessments of complexes 1-6 against HeLa and A549cell lines demonstrate that complexes with R=n-Bu (2, 4 and 6) exhibit superior activity than that with R=Me (1, 3 and 5). This presented study enriches various structures of organotin dicarboxylates and promising possibility of designing benign biological metal-based drugs.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0085">Experimental details</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0090">Materials and measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">Trimethyltin chloride, tri-<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-butyltin chloride, 6,6’-dithiodinicotinic acid, 2,2’-dithiodibenzoic acid, dithiodiglycolic acid and solvents were commercially available and were used without further purification. The melting points were obtained with a Kofler micro melting point apparatus and are uncorrected. Elemental analyses were performed with a PE-2400II apparatus. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet-5700 spectrometer using KBr discs. <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H, <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C, and <ce:sup loc="pre">119</ce:sup>Sn NMR spectra were recorded with a Varian Mercury Plus 400 spectrometer operating at 400, 100.6, and 149.2 MHz, respectively. The spectra were acquired at room temperature (298 K), unless otherwise specified. <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectra are broadband-proton-decoupled. The chemical shifts are reported in ppm with respect to the references and are stated relative to external tetramethylsilane (TMS) for <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR and to neat tetramethyltin for <ce:sup loc="pre">119</ce:sup>Sn NMR.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental details

Materials and measurements

Trimethyltin chloride, tri-n-butyltin chloride, 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid, 2,2'-dithiodibenzoic acid, dithiodiglycolic acid and solvents were commercially available and were used without further purification. The melting points were obtained with a Kofler micro melting point apparatus and are uncorrected. Elemental analyses were performed with a PE-2400II apparatus. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet-5700 spectrometer using KBr discs. 1H, 13C, and 119Sn NMR spectra were recorded with a Varian Mercury Plus 400 spectrometer operating at 400, 100.6, and 149.2MHz, respectively. The spectra were acquired at room temperature (298K), unless otherwise specified. 13C NMR spectra are broadband-proton-decoupled. The chemical shifts are reported in ppm with respect to the references and are stated relative to external tetramethylsilane (TMS) for 1H and 13C NMR and to neat tetramethyltin for 119Sn NMR.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0095">Cell culture and viability evaluation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0135" view="all">Assays were conducted using 96-well microplates. The cell viability was determined by MTT dye uptake. Briefly, human cervix cell lines (HeLa) and lung cancer cells (A549) were seeded (1 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> cells per well) into 96-well microtiter plates. RPMI-1640 containing antibiotics (100 μg per mL streptomycin and 100 U penicillin) and 10% fetal bovine serum were used as the culture medium. After 4 h pre-incubation of the cells in a 95% humidified 5% CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere at 37 °C, the complexes were added with a concentration of 0.01–100 μmol/L (diluted by DMSO solvent), followed by further incubation for 24 h and then the medium was removed. The MTT solution (5 mg mL<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) dissolved in PBS was added to each well and further incubated for another 4 h, then the supernatant was carefully discarded. Finally, 100 μL DMSO was added to every well, mixed, and measured on a multi-well plate reader (Bio-Rad iMark) at 570 nm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cell culture and viability evaluation

Assays were conducted using 96-well microplates. The cell viability was determined by MTT dye uptake. Briefly, human cervix cell lines (HeLa) and lung cancer cells (A549) were seeded (1×104cells per well) into 96-well microtiter plates. RPMI-1640 containing antibiotics (100μg per mL streptomycin and 100 U penicillin) and 10% fetal bovine serum were used as the culture medium. After 4h pre-incubation of the cells in a 95% humidified 5% CO2 atmosphere at 37°C, the complexes were added with a concentration of 0.01-100μmol/L (diluted by DMSO solvent), followed by further incubation for 24h and then the medium was removed. The MTT solution (5mgmL-1) dissolved in PBS was added to each well and further incubated for another 4h, then the supernatant was carefully discarded. Finally, 100μL DMSO was added to every well, mixed, and measured on a multi-well plate reader (Bio-Rad iMark) at 570nm.

Syntheses of complexes 1-6 

[(Me3Sn)2(O2CC5H3NS)2]n (1)

The reaction was carried out under nitrogen atmosphere by use of standard Schlenk techniques. H2L1 (0.308g, 1mmol) was added to the solution of methanol (30ml) together with potassium hydroxide (0.112g, 2mmol), and the mixture was stirred for 0.5 h until the H2L1 ligand was almost converted into its corresponding K-salt. Then trimethyltin chloride (0.398 g, 2 mmol) was added to react with the K-salt of the ligand, and the reaction was allowed to continue at 45°C for another 12h. After cooling down to room temperature, the solution was filtered. The solvent was gradually removed by evaporation under vacuum until a solid product was obtained. The solid was then recrystallized from diethyl ether, and colorless crystals of complex 1 were recovered. Yield: 49%. M.P. 233-235°C. Anal. Calc. for C18H24N2O4S2Sn2: C, 34.10; H, 3.82; N, 4.42%. Found: C, 34.32; H, 3.98; N, 4.29%. IR (KBr, cm-1): νas(COO), 1546; νs(COO), 1384; [Δν=ν(COO)as-ν(COO)s], 162; ν(SnC), 550; ν(SnO), 472. 1H NMR [DMSO-D6, ppm]: δ 8.85 (s, 2H, Ligand CH), 8.11, 7.57 (2d, 4H, Ligand CH), 0.51 (t, 18H, 2 J Sn-H=36Hz, SnCH3). 13C NMR [DMSO-D6, ppm]: δ 167.53 (COO), 159.81, 150.89, 138.74, 129.55, 118.91 (Ring-C), 1.69 (J Sn-C=266Hz, Sn CH3). 119Sn NMR [DMSO-D6, ppm]: δ -22.98.

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0135">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0170" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker SMART-1000 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. The data were integrated and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects using SAINT []. Absorption corrections were applied with SADABS []. The structures were solved by a direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:italic>2</ce:italic>
</ce:sup> using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package []. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were refined as riding on the corresponding non-hydrogen atoms. Additional details of the data collections and structural refinement parameters are provided in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and bond angles of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> are listed in  (Supporting Information).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker SMART-1000 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ=0.71073Å) radiation at room temperature. The data were integrated and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects using SAINT []. Absorption corrections were applied with SADABS []. The structures were solved by a direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F  2  using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package []. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were refined as riding on the corresponding non-hydrogen atoms. Additional details of the data collections and structural refinement parameters are provided in  . Selected bond lengths and bond angles of complexes 1-6 are listed in  (Supporting Information).

Syntheses of complexes 1-6 

[(Me3Sn)2(O2CC5H3NS)2]n (1)

The reaction was carried out under nitrogen atmosphere by use of standard Schlenk techniques. H2L1 (0.308g, 1mmol) was added to the solution of methanol (30ml) together with potassium hydroxide (0.112g, 2mmol), and the mixture was stirred for 0.5 h until the H2L1 ligand was almost converted into its corresponding K-salt. Then trimethyltin chloride (0.398 g, 2 mmol) was added to react with the K-salt of the ligand, and the reaction was allowed to continue at 45°C for another 12h. After cooling down to room temperature, the solution was filtered. The solvent was gradually removed by evaporation under vacuum until a solid product was obtained. The solid was then recrystallized from diethyl ether, and colorless crystals of complex 1 were recovered. Yield: 49%. M.P. 233-235°C. Anal. Calc. for C18H24N2O4S2Sn2: C, 34.10; H, 3.82; N, 4.42%. Found: C, 34.32; H, 3.98; N, 4.29%. IR (KBr, cm-1): νas(COO), 1546; νs(COO), 1384; [Δν=ν(COO)as-ν(COO)s], 162; ν(SnC), 550; ν(SnO), 472. 1H NMR [DMSO-D6, ppm]: δ 8.85 (s, 2H, Ligand CH), 8.11, 7.57 (2d, 4H, Ligand CH), 0.51 (t, 18H, 2 J Sn-H=36Hz, SnCH3). 13C NMR [DMSO-D6, ppm]: δ 167.53 (COO), 159.81, 150.89, 138.74, 129.55, 118.91 (Ring-C), 1.69 (J Sn-C=266Hz, Sn CH3). 119Sn NMR [DMSO-D6, ppm]: δ -22.98.

[(n-Bu3Sn)2(O2CC5H3NS)2]n (2)

The procedure is similar to that of complex 1. The mixture of H2L1 (0.308 g, 1 mmol) and potassium hydroxide (0.112 g, 2 mmol) was stirred for 0.5 h. Then tri-n-butyltin chloride (0.651 g, 2 mmol) was added to react for another 12 h at 45 °C and recrystallized from diethyl ether; colorless crystals of complex 2 were recovered. Yield: 42%. M.P. 77-79°C. Anal. Calc. for C36H60N2O4S2Sn2: C, 48.78; H, 6.82; N, 3.16%. Found: C, 48.96; H, 6.99; N, 3.28%. IR (KBr, cm-1): νas(COO), 1570; νs(COO), 1384; [Δν=ν(COO)as-ν(COO)s], 186; ν(SnC), 574; ν(SnO), 456. 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm): δ 9.06 (s, 2H, Ligand CH), 8.17, 7.60 (2d, 4H, Ligand CH), 1.33-1.68 (m, 36H, CH2CH2CH2), 0.91 (t, 18H, 2 J HH=8Hz, CH3). 13C NMR (CDCl3, ppm): δ 169.27 (COO), 162.27, 151.54, 138.74, 125.71, 118.71 (Ring-C), 27.76, 26.98, 16.69, 13.63 (n-butyl-C). 119Sn NMR (CDCl3, ppm): δ 126.95.

[(Me3Sn)2(O2CC6H4S)2]n (3) 

The procedure is similar to that of complex 1. The mixture of H2L2 (0.306 g, 1 mmol) and potassium hydroxide (0.112 g, 2 mmol) was stirred for 0.5 h. Then trimethyltin chloride (0.398 g, 2 mmol) was added to react for another 12 h at 45 °C and recrystallized from diethyl ether; transparent colorless crystals of complex 3 were obtained. Yield: 45%. M.P. 181-183°C. Anal. Calc. for C20H26O4S2Sn2: C, 38.01; H, 4.15%; Found: C, 38.29; H, 4.02%. IR (KBr, cm-1): νas(COO), 1577; νs(COO), 1384; [Δν=ν(COO)as-ν(COO)s], 193; ν(SnC), 512; ν(SnO), 480. 1H NMR (DMSO-D6, ppm): δ 7.19-7.94 (m, 8H, Ligand CH), 0.56 (t, 18H, 2 J Sn-H=32Hz, SnCH3). 13C NMR (DMSO-D6, ppm): δ 169.67 (COO), 125.03-138.77 (Ph-C), 0.86 (J Sn-C=251Hz, Sn CH3). 119Sn NMR (DMSO-D6, ppm): δ -3.56.

[(n-Bu3Sn)2(O2CC6H4S)2]n (4)

The procedure is similar to that of complex 1. The mixture of H2L2 (0.306 g, 1 mmol) and potassium hydroxide (0.112 g, 2 mmol) was stirred for 0.5 h. Then tri-n-butyltin chloride (0.651 g, 2 mmol) was added to react for another 12 h at 45 °C and recrystallized from diethyl ether; colorless crystals of complex 4 were recovered. Yield: 38%. M.P. 207-209°C. Anal. Calc. for C38H62O4S2Sn2: C, 51.60; H, 7.07%; Found: C, 51.78; H, 7.17%. IR (KBr, cm-1): νas(COO), 1546; νs(COO), 1383; [Δν=ν(COO)as-ν(COO)s], 163; ν(SnC), 575; ν(SnO), 453. 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm): δ 7.20-8.05 (m, 8H, Ligand CH), 1.41-1.70 (m, 36H, CH2CH2CH2), 0.92 (t, 18H, 2 J HH=8Hz, CH3). 13C NMR (CDCl3, ppm): δ 171.22 (COO), 125.06-139.74 (Ph-C), 27.87, 27.04, 16.84, 13.68 (n-butyl-C). 119Sn NMR (CDCl3, ppm): δ 125.90.

[(Me3Sn)2(O2CCH2S)2]n (5)

The procedure is similar to that of complex 1. The mixture of H2L3 (0.306 g, 1 mmol) and potassium hydroxide (0.112 g, 2 mmol) was stirred for 0.5 h. Then trimethyltin chloride (0.398 g, 2 mmol) was added to react for another 12 h at 45 °C and recrystallized from diethyl ether; colorless crystals of complex 5 were recovered. Yield: 50%. M.P. 173-175°C. Anal. Calc. for C10H22O4S2Sn2: C, 23.65; H, 4.37%; Found: C, 23.81; H, 4.48%. IR (KBr, cm-1): νas(COO), 1577; νs(COO), 1399; [Δν=ν(COO)as-ν(COO)s], 178; ν(SnC), 550; ν(SnO), 480. 1H NMR (DMSO-D6, ppm): δ 3.65 (s, 4H, SCH2), 0.62 (t, 18H, 2 J Sn-H=34Hz, SnCH3). 13C NMR (DMSO-D6, ppm): δ 172.08 (COO); 44.21 (SCH2); 1.39 (Sn CH3). 119Sn NMR (DMSO-D6, ppm): δ -21.68.

[(n-Bu3Sn)2(O2CCH2S)2]n (6)

The procedure is similar to that of complex 1. The mixture of H2L3 (0.306 g, 1 mmol) and potassium hydroxide (0.112 g, 2 mmol) was stirred for 0.5 h. Then tri-n-butyltin chloride (0.651 g, 2 mmol) was added to react for another 12 h at 45 °C and recrystallized from diethyl ether; colorless crystals of complex 6 were recovered. Yield: 52%. M.P. 70-73°C. Anal. Calc. for C28H58O4S2Sn2: C, 44.23; H, 7.69%; Found: C, 44.52; H, 7.51%. IR (KBr, cm-1): νas(COO), 1551; νs(COO), 1384; [Δν=ν(COO)as-ν(COO)s], 167; ν(SnC), 580; ν(SnO), 465. 1H NMR (CDCl3, ppm): δ 3.61 (s, 4H, SCH2), 1.27-1.66 (m, 36H, CH2CH2CH2), 0.91 (t, 18H, 2 J HH=8Hz, CH3). 13C NMR (CDCl3, ppm): δ 174.25 (COO); 42.13 (SCH2); 27.74, 27.02, 16.64, 13.64 (n-butyl-C). 119Sn NMR (CDCl3, ppm): δ 125.02.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0045">IR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The IR spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> were recorded in the range of 4000–400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and give valuable supporting information in structural elucidation. The typical absorptions in the region 453-480 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> and 512-580 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup>, which are absent in the spectrum of the potassium salts of ligands, are assigned to the Sn-O and Sn-C stretching vibration modes. Also, the strong absorption bands that appear at 1546–1577 and 1383–1399 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in these spectra are assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> moiety, respectively. All these values are well consistent with those detected in a number of organotin(IV)–oxygen derivatives []. In addition, as reported in the literature, the difference of Δ<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic> between the wavenumber for ν<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf>(COO) and ν<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf>(COO) allows one to distinguish the coordination modes of the ligand. When the Sn atoms are in coordination with the O atoms of the carboxylate group, the asymmetric vibration ν<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf> (COO) decreases and the symmetric vibration ν<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf> (COO) increases, so Δν decreases []. In the IR spectra of the potassium salts (K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L), the ν<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf> (COO) appear at 1584-1588 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> and ν<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf> (COO) at 1384-1391 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup>. The Δν values for three potassium salts are 197 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup>, 198 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> and 204 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup>. The Δν values for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> (162 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 186 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 193 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 163 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, 178 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, 167 cm<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) are less than that of corresponding potassium salts, which reveals that three ligands adopted bidentate coordination mode, without exception.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sectitle0050">NMR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra show the signals of the <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H proton are absent in these compounds, indicating the formation of Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond. In the <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectrum of complexes, the chemical shifts of protons on ligands exhibit signals at 7.57-9.06 ppm as singlets and doublets for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 7.19-8.05 ppm as multiplets for complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>-<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, and 3.61-3.65 ppm as singlets for complexes <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>-<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. Methyl protons (Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> moiety) of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> show triplet peaks at 0.51, 0.56 and 0.62 ppm respectively, along with the coupling constant <ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>(<ce:sup loc="post">119</ce:sup>Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H) [ 36 Hz for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 32 Hz for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 34 Hz for <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> ], which falls in the range of four-coordinated trigonal bipyramidal geometry around the tin atoms in solution state [,]. The <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph> skeleton of complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> appear in the range of 1.27-1.70 ppm as multiplets. And the terminal methyl groups of <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-butyl give characteristic signals at 0.91, 0.92 and 0.91 ppm as triplets respectively, with the coupling constant <ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>(<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H-<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H) = 8 Hz for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. The information accords well with what the IR data has revealed.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sectitle0055">Crystal structure descriptions</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0060">Crystal structures of complexes 1-2</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the Monoclinic system with space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2(1)/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, and is a 2D wavelike framework polymer in the crystalline state. As shown in

cln_elements.clean_text:
IR spectra

The IR spectra of complexes 1-6 were recorded in the range of 4000-400cm-1, and give valuable supporting information in structural elucidation. The typical absorptions in the region 453-480 cm-1 and 512-580 cm-1, which are absent in the spectrum of the potassium salts of ligands, are assigned to the Sn-O and Sn-C stretching vibration modes. Also, the strong absorption bands that appear at 1546-1577 and 1383-1399cm-1 in these spectra are assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the COO- moiety, respectively. All these values are well consistent with those detected in a number of organotin(IV)-oxygen derivatives []. In addition, as reported in the literature, the difference of Δν between the wavenumber for νas(COO) and νs(COO) allows one to distinguish the coordination modes of the ligand. When the Sn atoms are in coordination with the O atoms of the carboxylate group, the asymmetric vibration νas (COO) decreases and the symmetric vibration νs (COO) increases, so Δν decreases []. In the IR spectra of the potassium salts (K2L), the νas (COO) appear at 1584-1588 cm-1 and νs (COO) at 1384-1391 cm-1. The Δν values for three potassium salts are 197 cm-1, 198 cm-1 and 204 cm-1. The Δν values for complexes 1-6 (162 cm-1 for 1, 186 cm-1 for 2, 193 cm-1 for 3, 163 cm-1 for 4, 178 cm-1 for 5, 167 cm-1 for 6) are less than that of corresponding potassium salts, which reveals that three ligands adopted bidentate coordination mode, without exception.

NMR spectra

The 1H NMR spectra show the signals of the CO2H proton are absent in these compounds, indicating the formation of SnO bond. In the 1H NMR spectrum of complexes, the chemical shifts of protons on ligands exhibit signals at 7.57-9.06 ppm as singlets and doublets for complexes 1-2, 7.19-8.05 ppm as multiplets for complexes 3-4, and 3.61-3.65 ppm as singlets for complexes 5-6. Methyl protons (SnCH3 moiety) of complexes 1, 3 and 5 show triplet peaks at 0.51, 0.56 and 0.62 ppm respectively, along with the coupling constant 2 J(119Sn 1H) [ 36 Hz for 1, 32 Hz for 3 and 34 Hz for 5 ], which falls in the range of four-coordinated trigonal bipyramidal geometry around the tin atoms in solution state [,]. The CH2 CH2 CH2  skeleton of complexes 2, 4 and 6 appear in the range of 1.27-1.70 ppm as multiplets. And the terminal methyl groups of n-butyl give characteristic signals at 0.91, 0.92 and 0.91 ppm as triplets respectively, with the coupling constant 2 J(1H-1H) = 8 Hz for 2, 4 and 6. The information accords well with what the IR data has revealed.

Crystal structure descriptions

Crystal structures of complexes 1-2

Complex 1 crystallizes in the Monoclinic system with space group P2(1)/c, and is a 2D wavelike framework polymer in the crystalline state. As shown in  (a), the asymmetric unit contains two Me3Sn units and one deprotonated H2L1 ligand. In complex 1, the geometry around tin can be characterized by the geometric parameter τ, which can be calculated by using expression, τ = (β-α)/60. Here α is the axial angle, and β is the greater of the basal angles around Sn. τ value is equal to 1 for perfect trigonal bipyramidal, while zero for perfect square planar geometry. For complex 1, the value of τ is 0.84 indicating Sn atoms are situated in a distorted penta-coordinated trigonal bipyramid geometry []. The equatorial plane is composed of three carbon atoms from Me3Sn group, while the apical position is occupied by two oxygen atoms from two different H2L1 ligands. The O1Sn1O3 angle 175.7(4)º is close to linear arrangement. The sum of the angles subtended at the Sn1 atoms in the equatorial plane is 358.0°. The SnO bond lengths [Sn1O1 2.488(12) Å and Sn1O3 2.125(12) Å] are between the covalent bond length (2.13Å) and the van der Waals radii (3.69Å) [], indicating the compressed trigonal bipyramid environment of the metal ion.

Crystal structures of complex 3-4

Complex 3 crystallizes in the Monoclinic system with space group C2, and displays a 2D double-layer framework structure. As illustrated in  (a), the asymmetric unit is composed of two Me3Sn units and one deprotonated H2L2 ligand. Sn1 is also penta-coordinated by three carbon atoms (C15, C16, C17) from Me3Sn groups and two oxygen atoms (O1, O3) from two bridge ligands. In case of complex 3, the value of τ is 0.83 indicating the Sn coordination geometry is also described as distorted trigonal bipyramid [], which is the same as that of complex 1. Two oxygen atoms from two bridge ligands occupy the axial position and axial angle O1Sn1O3 is 174.5(3)°, which is close to linear arrangement. The sum of the angles subtended at the tin atom in the equatorial plane is 359.4° for Sn1, so that the Sn1, C15, C16, and C17 atoms are almost in the same plane. All SnO bond distances are in the range of 2.199(7)-2.416(7) Å, which lie between the covalent bond length (2.13Å) and the van der Waals radii (3.69Å) []. As displayed in (b), two tin atoms together with two H2L2 ligands construct a 22-membered macrocycle. And it is further linked to nearest-neighbor macrocycles to give rise to a 2D double-layer framework [ ]. The two aromatic rings of the ligand are twisted around the SS bond with a dihedral angle 82.505(495)°, which play a significant role in assisting in constructing 2D double-layer network [].

X-ray crystallographic study of complexes 5-6 

Complex 5 crystallizes in the Monoclinic system with space group P2(1)/n, and displays a 2D arched framework structure. Each of the tin atoms in complex 5 is essentially penta-coordinated, bound to three methyl groups and two carboxyl oxygen atoms. In complex 5, the value of τ is 0.774 showing the geometry of each tin atom can be described as a distorted trigonal bipyramid [], in which the apical positions are occupied by the oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups [ (a)]. The axial angle O1Sn1O3 is 174.94(11)º, and the sum of the equatorial angles around the Sn1 atom is 359.5°. The bond distances of SnO [2.193(3)-2.425(3)] are in the normal range of organotin complexes [].

As can be observed from , the IC50 (μmol/L) values of complexes with R=trimethyl against HeLa and A549cells are 31.34±2.41 and 47.57±2.62 (1), 27.71±1.16 and 57.25±3.03 (3), 40.20±2.68 and 60.87±3.58 (5), respectively. Whereas the IC50 (μmol/L) values of complexes with R=n-butyl against two cells are 0.42±0.05 and 0.62±0.08 (2), 0.41±0.03 and 0.65±0.09 (4), 0.55±0.06 and 0.73±0.10 (6). The experimental results indicate complexes with R=n-Bu (2, 4 and 6) exhibit stronger activity than that with R=Me (1, 3 and 5) against two cell lines, which is attributed to the presence of n-butyl groups showing higher lipophilic character than the methyl groups so as to facilitate binding to biological molecules []. Additionally, the in vitro antitumor activity of complexes with R=n-Bu (2, 4 and 6) is also higher than anti-cancer agent cisplatin.
